abstract.text: We report measurements of Time-Dependent CP asymmetries in several b→s penguin dominated hadronic B decays, where New Physics contributions may appear.
We find no significant discrepancies with respect to the Standard Model expectations.

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION
The measurement of CP violation in B meson decays provides crucial tests of the Standard Model (SM) and of the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) mechanism [1].

CKM-suppressed b→qq s (q = u, d, s) processes are dominated by a single loop (penguin) amplitude, that, assuming penguin dominance and neglecting higher order contributions, is expected to have the same phase β of the CKM-favored b → ccs transition [2].

body_text.text: In many extensions of the SM new heavy particles may appear in the loop [3], giving rise to deviations from this expectation.
These deviations are expected to be channel dependent.
The measurement of the phase difference between B 0 →K * (892) + π − and B 0 →K * (892) − π + can be used to constrain the CKM parameters in the (ρ,η) plane [4].
TIME-DEPENDENT DECAY RATES
The CKM phase β is accessible experimentally through the interference between the decay of mixed and unmixed B meson into a CP eigenstate.
This interference is observable through the time evolution of the decay.

ANALYSIS TECHNIQUE

Analyses presented here are based on a sample of 465 × 10 6 BB pairs (383 × 10 6 for B 0 →K 0 S π + π − ), collected at a center-of-mass energy equal to the mass of the ϒ (4S) resonance at the PEP-II asymmetric e + e − collider, at the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, and recorded by the BABAR detector [11].
The B meson is reconstructed into the above-mentioned CP eigenstates.

Background arises primarily from random combinations of particles in e + e − →qq events (q = u, d, s, c).
We suppress this background with requirements on the event shape variables and on the energy, invariant mass and particle identification signature of the decay products.
All events are required to have |∆t| < 20 ps and σ ∆t < 2.5 ps.

For each mode, results are obtained from an extended maximum likelihood fit with input variables ∆E, m ES , ∆t, and the output of a multivariate discriminant combining different event shape variables.
In ωK 0 S decay we also use ω mass and angular variables into the fit.
K 0 L momentum is determined using a B mass constraint, hence m ES is fully correlated to ∆E, and is not used into the fit in η ′ K 0 L modes.
The likelihood for a given event is the sum of the signal, continuum and the B-background components, weighted by their respective event yields.

RESULTS

In Table 1 and 2 we report the results for CP-violating parameters in analyses of the decay of a B 0 meson into a CP eigenstates and a three body non-CP eigenstates final state (DP analyses), respectively [12].
Results for K 0 S K + K − and K 0 S K 0 S K 0 S are preliminary.
In K 0 S π + π − and K 0 S K + K − low mass region, the likelihood function has two minima.
In B 0 → f 0 (980)K 0 S with f 0 (980)→K + K − , the second solution is disfavored by the result from f 0 (980)→π + π − .
In K 0 S π + π − analysis we measure A ch (K * (892) + π − ) = 0.20 ± 0.10 ± 0.02, where the first (second) error is statistical (systematic).
We also exclude −137°< ∆Φ(K * (892) + π − ) < −5°at 95% confidence level.
CONCLUSIONS
We have reported the results of measurements of CP-violating parameters in several b→s hadronic B meson decays.
All the results are consistent with the SM.
Results are in agreement with and supersede previous BABAR measurements.
